WARNINGWhen working with any decontaminant, take appropriate measures to avoid getting the substance into the eyes and mouth or onto the skin. In the event of eye, mouth, or skin contact, refer to the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for emergencies or first aid. WARNINGLiquids deployed by this system may be slippery. Every effort should be made to control accidental slippage and to avoid walking on areas where liquid has been spilled and/or applied. WARNINGNEVER operate the HMDS if an air line or discharge hose is worn/damaged, or if an air leak has been discovered. Once pressurized, a loose/leaking/damaged connection and/or hose may disconnect or rupture, potentially causing serious injury. WARNINGALWAYS treat the HMDS as though the discharge line(s) are pressurized. Once the system is pressurized, it will remain so until the air supply is turned off and the system is completely depressurized. A depressurized system can be identified by examining the air pressure gauge or the lack of a hissing sound. WARNINGALWAYS ensure that all connections, hoses, and nozzles are tightly attached while operating the HMDS. ALWAYS point all discharge devices in a safe direction.

WARNINGThe HMDS engine runs on diesel fuel. Observe all applicable precautions when handling, storing, or dispensing fuels. WARNINGThe Power Unit uses a 12V DC battery to supply electrical energy to the starter. To mitigate risks associated with the battery/charging system, do not remove or install any cables while the system is running or energized. Never allow any object to touch metal components in the battery box or other electrical components. WARNINGDisconnect all battery cables before servicing the HMDS engine. WARNINGSome parts of this system, especially the exhaust system, may be hot to the touch during and after operation. NEVER attempt to service internal components while the HMDS is running! Once the system is shut down, allow adequate time for components to cool before attempting to service any internal components. WARNINGThe operator shall have a firm grip and wide stance while discharging a hose from a spray nozzle. The HMDS propels solutions with significant force! Once the system is pressurized, never release the hose prior to closing the discharge nozzle/D-bale hand set and/or the Pump Control valve. A loose discharge hose will whip around violently and can cause serious injury or equipment damage. Always close the Pump Control valve on the Power Unit's Control Panel and relieve pressure from the discharge line before releasing the hose.

The High Mobility Decontamination System (HMDS) is a modular, diesel-driven system specifically designed for rapid, mobile decontamination missions for terrain and military equipment. The system is designed to be operated while mounted in the back of a M1083 vehicle or on a M1095 trailer, while stationary or mobile. The HMDS Power Unit uses a Diesel engine-powered air compressor to create and propel decontamination solutions through a 1.5" (3.81cm) pump. It deploys these solutions through vehicle- or trailer-mounted spray bars, a remote-control stanchion-mounted Monitor (water cannon), and non-collapsible hoses with D-Bale handset(s).  The HMDS is capable of drafting from external water sources, such as bulk tanks or natural bodies of water. In addition to the Power Unit, the HMDS incorporates two solution-mixing tanks, each with a fill capacity of 750 gallons. The tanks are constructed with internal baffles to minimize liquid movement and weight shift during transport.

The Tank Level Inspection Port is a capped, 2" diameter port located next to the Hopper/Blender. The plastic cap is secured with a metal ?dog tag chain? lanyard. This port contains a measuring tape which is marked in 100 gallon increments on its back side. This enables visual measurement of the amount of liquid in the tank. 1" of tape represents approximately 20 gallons of liquid.  To measure the fluid level, gently pull upwards on the tape until a ?catch? is felt. Then, read the measurement.  To secure the tape, gently push it back down into the tube and re-cap the port.  The tape may also be left out of the port to watch the tank level rise or fall.

The Front Spray Bar (FSB) is used to disperse fluid from the front of a truck. It is made of stainless steel and is fed by the 1" diameter Green Banded hose. The middle section is 98" long and comes equipped with mounting brackets, as well as two capped ends that are used to attach the right- and left- ?wings.?  The mounting brackets are set up to mount the FSB to armored M1083 trucks. The bracket must be inverted in order to mount the FSB to the unarmored versions of the M1083 trucks. Two (2) 1" diameter clevis pins are used to hold the brackets onto the clevis fittings on the front of the truck.  Without the extension wings, the FSB will cover approximately 16' (wide). Ensure that the caps with gaskets are in place and locked down. Failure to do so will result in liquid spraying up the side(s) of the truck.  The right- and left-wings extend the FSB?s overall length by 4' each (8' overall), for a total spray pattern that is approximately 32' wide. The right wing is marked with an ?R? and red bands, while the left wing is marked with an ?L? and green bands. To avoid damaging the FSB or the vehicle, each wing can swivel backwards if it strikes an object.  To add the wings to the FSB, detach the camlock caps on each end of the middle section. Then, attach the wings using the Instalock fittings. Make certain that there is a rubber gasket in the fitting or the FSB won?t operate properly.  The center nozzles on the middle spray bar and the inner nozzles on the wings point approximately 45 degrees forward from the vertical. The outer nozzles on the wings point outward and downward.

The Agitator mixes tank contents and keeps concentrated decontaminant solutions mixed while the system is running. It is important to keep the tanks agitated, especially when they contain concentrated bleach solutions or slurries. The Agitator input is a 1" diameter, right-angled fitting, which is fed by the Yellow Banded Agitator hoses. It is located on top of the tank, next to the Hopper/Blender. Please be aware that the Agitator cannot be used while drafting or discharging a tank via Discharge Port #1.

The Front Spray Bar hose is used to connect the Front Spray Bar port on the Power Unit to the Front Spray Bar. It is 25' long, has a 1" diameter, is made of Red Booster Hose material, and is marked with a Green Band.  The hose is routed over the cab of the truck and can be held in place with magnets that are stored in the Accessory Box of the De-Icer Kit. It can also be attached to the Agitator on the main (truck) tank. The Instalock connectors on these hoses require two hands to attach and detach.

The HMDS includes a hose kit to attach the Power Unit to the Tanks and the various discharge functions. There are 15 hoses in the kit. Hoses are stored in the baskets on top of the tanks to allow them to dry properly. The hoses that deliver pressurized water are made of red ?booster hose? material (the same material used for the M12A1 discharge hoses) that is durable and will withstand caustic bleach solutions. The larger diameter (1.5") hoses have EZLink camlock connectors for fast and easy, one-handed installation and de-installation. The smaller diameter (1") hoses use Instalock camlock connectors.  The suction and drafting hoses are made of blue-colored, reinforced PVC to retain rigidity under suction. The suction and drafting hoses are always connected with 1.5" Instalock camlock style connectors. The drafting hoses have male fittings whereas all of the other hoses are equipped with female fittings.

The Monitor is a water cannon used for large area/long distance decontamination. It can be configured to operate either manually or with the wired Remote-Control Box. There are 2 manual- control hand wheel knobs on the Monitor that can be used to move it if there is no power being supplied. It is made of stainless steel and is fed by the 17' long, 1.5" diameter, Purple Banded hose via an EZLink connector.  The Monitor is comprised of three (3) major components: the Monitor head, a ?haloed? Stanchion to protect the Monitor head, and a wired Remote-Control Box.  Selector Valve #2 on the Power Unit has two functions related to the Monitor:  Monitor: This setting allows liquid to flow to the Monitor constantly once the Pump Control Valve is opened.  Remote Monitor: This setting causes the flow of water to be controlled by the wired Remote-Control Box. Liquid will begin to flow to the Monitor when the switch on the controller is engaged, and will immediately stop when the switch is released. The nozzle control switch (?Fog/Stream?) controls the ?blabber? actuator on the Stream & Fog nozzle; the ?stream? is a straight flow of liquid, whereas the ?fog? is of lower pressure, and fan shaped.

The stainless steel Hopper/Blender is used to aid in mixing powdered, liquid, and granular decontaminant materials into a tank. It has a 16" diameter and the funnel section is 22" deep. It has a plastic lid, which is attached by a lanyard, and a removable stainless steel screen. The screen has a handle on top and several 1" diameter holes across its surface. The holes assist with breaking up clumps of powdered or granular decontaminant that could clog the 1.5" diameter funnel output spout.  The Hopper/Blender is primarily fed by a 1.5" EZLink camlock fitting on the White Banded Hopper Hose. Alternatively, it can be fed by the Red Banded Discharge Hoses, or any other 1.5" diameter hose in the HMDS hose kit. The Hopper/Blender is located next to the Agitator and has two (2) 1/2" stainless steel bars in the funnel section. These bars support the removable screen and help prevent objects from accidentally falling into the tank. If there are ?clumps? of decontaminant on the bars or screen, use a disposable dipstick made of wood or plastic (supplied by the unit) to break them down to a size which will allow the clumps to feed through the screen.  WARNING! DO NOT use a hammer, metal objects, or excessive force that could cause damage to the Hopper.  If ?clumps? are not easily breakable, simply remove them from the Hopper. WARNING! Avoid sticking fingers or gloved hands into the screen holes, as this may result in serious cuts.

The HMDS has two 750-gallon tanks with incorporated skids. Tank Specifications:Weight (empty): ~1,000 lbs.  Weight (full of water): ~7,500 lbs.  Overall Dimensions (with skid, without storage basket): 92" L x 80" W x 43.5" H Actual Dimensions of the Tank (outside-to-outside): 68" L x 78" W x 36" H   The tanks are built using a 4-way, modular platform skid design which allows for 360-degree forklifting capability. EMPTY tanks can also be lifted from underneath with a forklift, using extended forks or slings and an overhead crane or wrecker. They can be loaded from either the rear or the sides of transport vehicles.  Both tanks have an approximate 13" notched bottom lip (skid cutouts to the front to accommodate the monitor) on the front ends, which butts the tank against the front wall of the truck bed. This helps in preventing slippage and damage to the tank itself.  Each tank is equipped with a Hopper/Blender assembly and fill connection, Agitator assembly and fill connection, tank level indicator port, and a ball valve fluid output/drain with a 1.5" camlock. WARNING! Although the tanks are sturdy and supported with internal baffles, do not stand on them! They may become very slippery and can create a slip and fall hazard.

The Monitor is equipped with a wired Remote-Control Box that can be operated from the cab of the truck or from the ground. The cable for the Remote-Control Box should be routed through the partially open truck window.

The Rear Spray Bar (RSB) is used to disperse fluid from the back of a truck or trailer. The RSB is approximately 8' long overall and will spray in a pattern that is approximately 16' wide. The brackets are equipped with 1" diameter clevis pins to fasten the RSB brackets to the rear clevis fixtures on the truck or the trailer. When mounted on the back of a truck, the RSB can be fed by a single 1" diameter Orange Banded hose. However, when the RSB is mounted to the back of a trailer, both Orange Banded hoses must be connected using a 1" male-male adapter in order to reach the Power Unit. The central nozzles on the RSB point downward (near vertical) and the outer nozzles point outward from the sides. There is a bolt on the bottom of each of the two RSB brackets that the operator can use to adjust the angle of the RSB. This should be done to ensure the nozzles are pointing downward as much as possible.
There are four (4) Inspection/Cleanout Ports incorporated into each tank . They can be used to assist with tank cleaning and content inspection. These ports have lanyard-attached camlock caps.

The Discharge hoses and Short Discharge hoses are used to disperse fluid with D-Bale handles (guns) and other nozzles stored in the Accessory Box.  The two main Discharge hoses are 50' long, have a 1.5" diameter, and are marked with a single Red Band. Using a male-male adapter, they can be connected together to provide a longer reach.  The two Short Discharge hoses are 12' long, have a 1.5" diameter, and are marked with Double Red Bands. They are used to connect the D-Bale handles or the Hopper/Blender to the main (truck) tank. These hoses can also be used to discharge fluid from the back of the Power Unit to a dump tank on the ground.

The truck Cab Magnets can be used to keep the hoses secure over the cab of the truck and off of the windshield.  The Tailgate Magnets keep the hoses from sagging and provide additional support.  Both sets of magnets are rated at 50 lbs. each. Connection clamps, zip-ties, or 550 parachute cord can be used to attach the hose to the magnet. You can also use plastic coiled hose protectors to aid in protecting the hoses where they bend over the truck cab or tailgate.
Never use antifreeze with Super Tropical Bleach (STB). A heat-releasing reaction will occur.

The Vertical Draft hose is used to draft water vertically (from a stream, pond, ocean, or a tank on the ground) into the truck and/or trailer tank. It is 20' long, has a 1" diameter, is fitted with 1.5" male fittings on both ends, and is marked with a single Blue Band. This hose attaches to the Draft Input port on the front of the Power Unit.  The Horizontal Draft hose is meant to draft water from a water source on the same level as the recipient tank. It is 60' long, has a 1" diameter, is fitted with 1.5" male fittings on both ends, and is marked with Double Blue Bands.  ALWAYS use the Filter Basket when drafting to reduce the risk of foreign objects getting lodged in the Power Unit or the tank(s).

The Hopper/Blender hose is used to connect the Power Unit to a tank that is mounted on the trailer or on the ground. It is 35' long, has a 1.5" diameter, is made of Red Booster Hose material, and is marked with a White Band. It also has EZLink connectors for quick, one-handed connection and removal.  This hose attaches via the Hopper/Blender on the tank or can be used to fill the tank from the bottom at the Tank Main Drain. It can also be used as an intermediate length discharge hose.

The 8' long Spray Bars are designed to be universally fit-enabled by an adjustable slide bracket mechanism. This allows for up to 2? of lateral adjustability during installation. This mechanism also allows for interchangeability between the Front Spray Bar (FSB) mounts on the M1083 variants. The spray bars are held in place with the clevis pins on the shackle mounts. The spray bars themselves are designed with four (4) ?", 80-degree fan spray tips. Each tip produces ~60 psi of pressure. The FSB also has attachable ?wings? or outriggers to extend the spraying pattern wider (up to 32' wide) using a total of 8 fan spray tips/nozzles. The Rear Spray Bar (RSB) is also a universal fit. It can be mounted on the rear of the M1083 FMTV style trucks and the M1095 series trailers.  WARNING! NEVER stand on the spray bars. Doing so may cause injury and/or system damage.

Ensure that the pin for the davit pocket is used for the Stanchion. Position the Monitor?s tank input to point towards the Power Unit to avoid kinks in the hose. The ?halo? on the top of the Stanchion serves to protect and act as a lifting handle for the Monitor. The Monitor can be operated either manually or by the wired Remote-Control Box. It can be operated while dismounted or from inside the truck?s cab.  The Monitor Electrical Connector on the back of the Power Unit supplies power (12 VDC) to the Monitor and its controller. It also establishes the connection to turn the water flow on/off while the system is in "Remote Monitor" mode.
